doc_description: This document provides a comprehensive overview of Medicare and the Medicare Secondary Payer (MSP) Act, detailing its history, eligibility, coverage, and legal cases related to MSP Recovery. It also includes data sources, security measures, and the company's approach to maximizing recoveries.

structure.title: Medicare: Generally
structure.summary: This section provides a historical overview of Medicare, highlighting its inception in 1965, expansion in 1972, and its current role in covering 59 million Americans. It also discusses Medicare's financial impact on federal and national health spending.
structure.text: Medicare was created in 1965 for those 65 and over and expanded in 1972 to include individuals under 65 with certain disabilities. Today, it covers 59 million Americans and accounts for 15% of federal spending in 2016 and 20% of national health spending in 2015.

structure.title: Medicare: Who is Eligible?
structure.summary: Eligibility for Medicare is outlined, including criteria for those over 65 and under 65 with specific medical conditions. The section explains the waiting period for SSDI recipients and exceptions for ESRD and ALS patients.
structure.text: Individuals over 65 are eligible for Medicare Part A if they or their spouse qualify for Social Security and have paid payroll taxes for 10 years. Under 65 individuals with SSDI become eligible after a 2-year waiting period, with exceptions for ESRD and ALS.

structure.title: Medicare: What is Covered
structure.summary: This section details the coverage provided by Medicare, including hospital stays, physician services, and prescription drugs. It introduces the different parts of Medicare: Part A, Part B, Part C (Medicare Advantage), and Part D (Drug Benefit Program).
structure.text: Medicare covers hospital stays, physician services, and prescription drugs. Traditional Medicare includes Part A and Part B, while Part D covers outpatient prescription drugs. Medicare Advantage (Part C) offers an alternative through private health plans.

structure.title: Traditional Medicare
structure.summary: Traditional Medicare, also known as Original Medicare or Fee For Service Medicare, is introduced. It is the standard form of Medicare coverage, providing a baseline for services covered under Parts A and B.
structure.text: Traditional Medicare, also known as Original Medicare or Fee For Service Medicare, provides coverage for hospital and medical services under Parts A and B.

structure.title: Medicare Part A
structure.summary: Medicare Part A covers inpatient hospital stays, skilled nursing facility stays, home health visits, and hospice care. It includes deductibles and coinsurance, with providers paid on a fee-for-service basis.
structure.text: Part A covers inpatient hospital stays, skilled nursing facility stays, home health visits, and hospice care. Deductibles and coinsurance apply, with providers paid on a fee-for-service basis according to CMS contracts.

structure.title: Medicare Part B
structure.summary: Medicare Part B covers physician visits, outpatient services, and preventative services. It includes deductibles and coinsurance, with certain services exempt from these charges. Providers are paid on a fee-for-service basis.
structure.text: Part B covers physician visits, outpatient services, and preventative services. Deductibles and coinsurance apply, except for wellness visits and certain preventative services. Providers are paid on a fee-for-service basis.

structure.title: Medicare Part D
structure.summary: Medicare Part D is a voluntary program that helps cover outpatient prescription drug costs. It involves monthly premiums and cost-sharing, with additional assistance for low-income beneficiaries.
structure.text: Part D covers outpatient prescription drugs through private plans. Enrollees pay monthly premiums and cost-sharing, with catastrophic coverage for high drug costs. Financial assistance is available for low-income beneficiaries.

structure.title: Medicare Advantage
structure.summary: Medicare Advantage, or Part C, allows beneficiaries to enroll in private health plans that cover all Medicare-covered Part A and B benefits, and typically Part D benefits. Providers are paid on a capitated basis.
structure.text: Medicare Advantage, also known as Part C, offers private health plans like HMOs and PPOs that cover all Medicare-covered Part A and B benefits, and often Part D benefits. Providers are paid on a capitated basis.

structure.title: The U.S. Federal Budget In 2016
structure.summary: This section provides an overview of the U.S. federal budget in 2016, focusing on health spending and its major sources of funds.
structure.text: An overview of the U.S. federal budget in 2016, highlighting health spending and its major sources of funds.

structure.title: Timeline
structure.summary: A timeline of significant events in the history of Medicare and the MSP Act, including the enactment of Medicare in 1965 and the creation of the MSP Act in 1980.
structure.text: Key events include the enactment of Medicare in 1965, the creation of the MSP Act in 1980, and the establishment of Medicare Advantage in 1997.

structure.title: Legal Cases and MSP Recovery
structure.summary: This section covers various legal cases involving MSP Recovery, highlighting court decisions and their implications for the MSP Act and Medicare Advantage Organizations.
structure.text: The section discusses legal cases such as U.S. v. Baxter, United Seniors Association v. Philip Morris, and MSP Recovery v. Allstate, focusing on the legal interpretations and implications for MSP Recovery and Medicare Advantage Organizations.

structure.title: Data Sources and Security
structure.summary: An overview of the data sources used by MSP Recovery and the security measures in place to protect this data, including encryption and compliance with HIPAA standards.
structure.text: MSP Recovery utilizes various data sources such as CMS NPI, traffic crash reports, and FDA data. Security measures include data encryption, integrity audits, and compliance with HIPAA standards.
